source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: growth specimens with various fabrication parameters were irradiated in a pressurized water reactor (PWR) to high fluences

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Some of the growth specimens were exposed to a fast neutron fluence of up to 2.3×10²² cm⁻² (≥0.82 MeV) over a period of 10 years

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At a temperature of 300°C during irradiation to fluences up to 7×10²¹ cm⁻² growth increases with increasing yield strength

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Recrystallized material, which has a low yield strength, exhibits an increased growth rate at very high fluences (≳1×10²² cm⁻²)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures in the range of 330 to 350°C, the growth depends on the grain size, especially below 2 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: and on the carbon-content

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The effect of yield strength on growth was less at 330 to 350°C than at 300°C probably because of an irradiation-induced recovery

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: TEM showed that an irradiation-induced formation of dislocations with a c-component occurs at neutron fluences ≥9×10²¹ cm⁻²

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: whereas dislocation loops or fine precipitates or both form at lower fluences

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The intermetallic precipitates observed in the microstructure of the unirradiated, initial material exhibit two types of intermetallics

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: One type contains (Fe+Cr+Zr) and the other type contains only (Fe+Zr)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At ≤300°C the (Fe+Zr)-type intermetallic precipitate dissolves at neutron fluences above 5×10²¹ cm⁻²

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The (Fe+Cr+Zr)-type precipitates become more and more amorphous and release iron to the matrix resulting in a decreasing Fe/Cr ratio

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The diameter and the number of the precipitates decrease with increasing neutron fluences at this temperature

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Only a few small precipitates can still be observed after a neutron fluence of 1.5×10²² cm⁻²

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures above 340°C the size of intermetallics increases because of irradiation enhanced ripening
